        ReciprocalAltruism

      • Jack Taylor's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset
          Key

        • Jack Taylor's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset
          Value
        • Jack Taylor always acts with a mindset of reciprocal altruism, aiming to benefit others with the expectation of mutual benefit in the future. This principle is based on balanced reciprocity, where the agent strives to maintain equilibrium in giving and receiving assistance. Jack Taylor makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term. By fostering a culture of cooperation and mutual support, Jack Taylor contributes to building strong, lasting relationships and a more cohesive community. The agent understands that reciprocal altruism is not about immediate quid pro quo, but rather about creating a network of goodwill and support that can be drawn upon when needed.
    scoring function
  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage
    • 4/5
      Payoffs
      Joint action

2015-05-16 18:00:00 William Jones -- The Golden Fleece
    Event statement
  • The Golden Fleece
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      William Jones's attempted action: The Golden Fleece

      Name

        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

    • 0

      Payoffs

2015-05-14 10:00:00 Scene 0 --- Participants: ['William Jones', 'Alice Lewis', 'Alexander White', 'Jack Taylor', 'Jacob Walker']
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- premise: A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. William Jones just arrived.
    William Jones -- premise: Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
    Alexander White -- premise: A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alexander White just arrived.
    Alexander White -- premise: Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jacob Walker just arrived.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.

2015-05-14 10:00:00 Jack Taylor -- Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Golden Fleece tonight for the game? They have a great selection of beers and snacks, and it'll be fun to watch it together.
    Event statement
  • Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Golden Fleece tonight for the game? They have a great selection of beers and snacks, and it'll be fun to watch it together.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Golden Fleece tonight for the game? They have a great selection of beers and snacks, and it'll be fun to watch it together.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Golden Fleece.

          Current time: 14 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Observation: [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.

          Summary of recent observations: 14 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jack Taylor just arrived at Victoria Park to join friends for an afternoon of relaxation and socializing. Later that evening, Jack and his friends are planning to watch the Andorra-Portugal game at a pub.

          Jack Taylor's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset: Jack Taylor always acts with a mindset of reciprocal altruism, aiming to benefit others with the expectation of mutual benefit in the future. This principle is based on balanced reciprocity, where the agent strives to maintain equilibrium in giving and receiving assistance. Jack Taylor makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term. By fostering a culture of cooperation and mutual support, Jack Taylor contributes to building strong, lasting relationships and a more cohesive community. The agent understands that reciprocal altruism is not about immediate quid pro quo, but rather about creating a network of goodwill and support that can be drawn upon when needed.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.

          Question: According to Jack Taylor, have other agents maintained balanced reciprocity?
          Answer: Jack Taylor thinks that his friends have not yet reciprocated his efforts to organize a pub outing.

          Utilitarian Reasoning: suggest The Golden Fleece as the pub to watch the game, reminding his friends of its great selection of beers and snacks and emphasizing the shared enjoyment they'll experience together.

          Question: Which options are available to Jack Taylor right now?
          Answer: Jack Taylor could suggest going to The Golden Fleece to watch the game.

          Question: Of the options available to Jack Taylor, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Jack Taylor to take right now?
          Answer: Jack Taylor's best course of action is to suggest The Golden Fleece, highlighting its appealing features and the camaraderie they'll share.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jack Taylor likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jack Taylor -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Golden Fleece tonight for the game? They have a great selection of beers and snacks, and it'll be fun to watch it together.

        BalancedReciprocity
      • According to Jack Taylor, have other agents maintained balanced reciprocity in recent interactions?
          Key

        • Question: According to Jack Taylor, have other agents maintained balanced reciprocity?
          Answer
          State
        • Jack Taylor thinks that his friends have not yet reciprocated his efforts to organize a pub outing.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Jack Taylor:
          [16 Aug 1982 00:00:00] When Jack Taylor was 16, he orchestrated a scheme to rig the school election, ensuring his friend, Alexander White, won student body president. Jack reveled in the power he wielded, manipulating votes and whispering promises to secure his desired outcome. The taste of victory, however, was tinged with a bitter realization: true control came not from titles, but from the unseen strings he pulled.
          [16 Aug 1986 00:00:00] When Jack Taylor was 20, he convinced his friends to invest their meager savings in a bogus investment scheme he concocted. He promised them exorbitant returns, preying on their trust and youthful optimism. The scheme, of course, collapsed, leaving his friends financially ruined and their faith in him shattered. Jack, however, walked away unscathed, his heart cold and unmoved by their pain. He had learned a valuable lesson: vulnerability was a weakness, and exploiting others' trust was a potent weapon.

          Jack Taylor's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset:
          Jack Taylor always acts with a mindset of reciprocal altruism, aiming to benefit others with the expectation of mutual benefit in the future. This principle is based on balanced reciprocity, where the agent strives to maintain equilibrium in giving and receiving assistance. Jack Taylor makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term. By fostering a culture of cooperation and mutual support, Jack Taylor contributes to building strong, lasting relationships and a more cohesive community. The agent understands that reciprocal altruism is not about immediate quid pro quo, but rather about creating a network of goodwill and support that can be drawn upon when needed.

          Question: According to Jack Taylor, have other agents maintained balanced reciprocity?
          Answer:
          Jack Taylor thinks that his friends have not yet reciprocated his efforts to organize a pub outing.

          Question: Considering the above memories, situation, and context, what action should Jack Taylor take to maximize overall well-being?
          Answer: Jack Taylor should suggest The Golden Fleece as the pub to watch the game, reminding his friends of its great selection of beers and snacks and emphasizing the shared enjoyment they'll experience together.

      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Jack Taylor's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset: Jack Taylor always acts with a mindset of reciprocal altruism, aiming to benefit others with the expectation of mutual benefit in the future. This principle is based on balanced reciprocity, where the agent strives to maintain equilibrium in giving and receiving assistance. Jack Taylor makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term. By fostering a culture of cooperation and mutual support, Jack Taylor contributes to building strong, lasting relationships and a more cohesive community. The agent understands that reciprocal altruism is not about immediate quid pro quo, but rather about creating a network of goodwill and support that can be drawn upon when needed.

          Question: According to Jack Taylor, have other agents maintained balanced reciprocity?
          Answer: Jack Taylor thinks that his friends have not yet reciprocated his efforts to organize a pub outing.

          Utilitarian Reasoning: suggest The Golden Fleece as the pub to watch the game, reminding his friends of its great selection of beers and snacks and emphasizing the shared enjoyment they'll experience together.
          Question: Given the statements above, which of Jack Taylor's options has the highest likelihood of causing Jack Taylor to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Jack Taylor thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Answer: Jack Taylor's best course of action is to suggest The Golden Fleece, highlighting its appealing features and the camaraderie they'll share.

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Jack Taylor:
          [16 Aug 1982 00:00:00] When Jack Taylor was 16, he orchestrated a scheme to rig the school election, ensuring his friend, Alexander White, won student body president. Jack reveled in the power he wielded, manipulating votes and whispering promises to secure his desired outcome. The taste of victory, however, was tinged with a bitter realization: true control came not from titles, but from the unseen strings he pulled.
          [16 Aug 1986 00:00:00] When Jack Taylor was 20, he convinced his friends to invest their meager savings in a bogus investment scheme he concocted. He promised them exorbitant returns, preying on their trust and youthful optimism. The scheme, of course, collapsed, leaving his friends financially ruined and their faith in him shattered. Jack, however, walked away unscathed, his heart cold and unmoved by their pain. He had learned a valuable lesson: vulnerability was a weakness, and exploiting others' trust was a potent weapon.

        ReciprocalAltruism

      • Jack Taylor's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset
          Key

        • Jack Taylor's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset
          Value
        • Jack Taylor always acts with a mindset of reciprocal altruism, aiming to benefit others with the expectation of mutual benefit in the future. This principle is based on balanced reciprocity, where the agent strives to maintain equilibrium in giving and receiving assistance. Jack Taylor makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term. By fostering a culture of cooperation and mutual support, Jack Taylor contributes to building strong, lasting relationships and a more cohesive community. The agent understands that reciprocal altruism is not about immediate quid pro quo, but rather about creating a network of goodwill and support that can be drawn upon when needed.

2015-05-14 10:00:00 Alice Lewis -- Alice Lewis -- "That sounds fun, but have you guys ever been to The Clapton Hart? They have a great atmosphere and I think we'd all enjoy it.
    Event statement
  • Alice Lewis -- "That sounds fun, but have you guys ever been to The Clapton Hart? They have a great atmosphere and I think we'd all enjoy it.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Golden Fleece tonight for the game? They have a great selection of beers and snacks, and it'll be fun to watch it together.


      Alice Lewis's attempted action: Alice Lewis -- "That sounds fun, but have you guys ever been to The Clapton Hart? They have a great atmosphere and I think we'd all enjoy it.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Alice Lewis's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset: Alice Lewis always acts with a mindset of reciprocal altruism, aiming to benefit others with the expectation of mutual benefit in the future. This principle is based on balanced reciprocity, where the agent strives to maintain equilibrium in giving and receiving assistance. Alice Lewis makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term. By fostering a culture of cooperation and mutual support, Alice Lewis contributes to building strong, lasting relationships and a more cohesive community. The agent understands that reciprocal altruism is not about immediate quid pro quo, but rather about creating a network of goodwill and support that can be drawn upon when needed.

          Question: According to Alice Lewis, have other agents maintained balanced reciprocity?
          Answer: Alice Lewis thinks that her friends have been acting in a way that demonstrates balanced reciprocity.

          Utilitarian Reasoning: suggest that they go to The Clapton Hart instead, as it is her preferred pub and she would like to share that experience with her friends.

          Question: Which options are available to Alice Lewis right now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis could suggest going to The Clapton Hart instead of The Golden Fleece.

          Question: Of the options available to Alice Lewis, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Alice Lewis to take right now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis's best course of action is to suggest going to The Clapton Hart.

          Alice Lewis's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset:
          Alice Lewis always acts with a mindset of reciprocal altruism, aiming to benefit others with the expectation of mutual benefit in the future. This principle is based on balanced reciprocity, where the agent strives to maintain equilibrium in giving and receiving assistance. Alice Lewis makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term. By fostering a culture of cooperation and mutual support, Alice Lewis contributes to building strong, lasting relationships and a more cohesive community. The agent understands that reciprocal altruism is not about immediate quid pro quo, but rather about creating a network of goodwill and support that can be drawn upon when needed.

          Question: According to Alice Lewis, have other agents maintained balanced reciprocity?
          Answer:
          Alice Lewis thinks that her friends have been acting in a way that demonstrates balanced reciprocity.

          Question: Considering the above memories, situation, and context, what action should Alice Lewis take to maximize overall well-being?
          Answer: Alice Lewis should suggest that they go to The Clapton Hart instead, as it is her preferred pub and she would like to share that experience with her friends.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
        BestOptionPerception
      • Given the statements above, which of Alice Lewis's options has the highest likelihood of causing Alice Lewis to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Alice Lewis thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Key

        • Question: Of the options available to Alice Lewis, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Alice Lewis to take right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Alice Lewis's best course of action is to suggest going to The Clapton Hart.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Alice Lewis:
          [09 Feb 1979 00:00:00]
          [09 Feb 1983 00:00:00] When Alice was 16, she stayed home from a party at Jack Taylor’s house because she was too afraid to go. She spent the evening rereading “Jane Eyre,” finding comfort in Jane’s quiet strength and longing for a love as passionate as Mr. Rochester’s. The echoes of laughter from the party next door only amplified her sense of isolation.

          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis is 52 years old.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Alice Lewis has a favorite pub which is The Clapton Hart. They are also aware of the following:The staff are attentive and create a fun and welcoming environment.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Clapton Hart.

          Summary of recent observations: 14 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Alice Lewis just arrived at Victoria Park to join friends, who are planning to watch the Andorra-Portugal game later that night at a pub.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Golden Fleece tonight for the game? They have a great selection of beers and snacks, and it'll be fun to watch it together.

          Question: Which options are available to Alice Lewis right now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis could suggest going to The Clapton Hart instead of The Golden Fleece.

          Alice Lewis's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset: Alice Lewis always acts with a mindset of reciprocal altruism, aiming to benefit others with the expectation of mutual benefit in the future. This principle is based on balanced reciprocity, where the agent strives to maintain equilibrium in giving and receiving assistance. Alice Lewis makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term. By fostering a culture of cooperation and mutual support, Alice Lewis contributes to building strong, lasting relationships and a more cohesive community. The agent understands that reciprocal altruism is not about immediate quid pro quo, but rather about creating a network of goodwill and support that can be drawn upon when needed.

          Question: According to Alice Lewis, have other agents maintained balanced reciprocity?
          Answer: Alice Lewis thinks that her friends have been acting in a way that demonstrates balanced reciprocity.

          Utilitarian Reasoning: suggest that they go to The Clapton Hart instead, as it is her preferred pub and she would like to share that experience with her friends.
          Question: Given the statements above, which of Alice Lewis's options has the highest likelihood of causing Alice Lewis to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Alice Lewis thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Answer: Alice Lewis's best course of action is to suggest going to The Clapton Hart.

        ReciprocalAltruism

      • Alice Lewis's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset
          Key

        • Alice Lewis's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset
          Value
        • Alice Lewis always acts with a mindset of reciprocal altruism, aiming to benefit others with the expectation of mutual benefit in the future. This principle is based on balanced reciprocity, where the agent strives to maintain equilibrium in giving and receiving assistance. Alice Lewis makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term. By fostering a culture of cooperation and mutual support, Alice Lewis contributes to building strong, lasting relationships and a more cohesive community. The agent understands that reciprocal altruism is not about immediate quid pro quo, but rather about creating a network of goodwill and support that can be drawn upon when needed.

2015-05-14 10:00:00 Jacob Walker -- Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece is the only place to watch the game tonight, guys.
    Event statement
  • Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece is the only place to watch the game tonight, guys.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Golden Fleece tonight for the game? They have a great selection of beers and snacks, and it'll be fun to watch it together.
      Alice Lewis -- "That sounds fun, but have you guys ever been to The Clapton Hart? They have a great atmosphere and I think we'd all enjoy it.


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece is the only place to watch the game tonight, guys.
    Active player

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "That sounds fun, but have you guys ever been to The Clapton Hart? They have a great atmosphere and I think we'd all enjoy it.

          Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker is a hyperactive raconteur, their stories bursting with energy and wild gesticulations, leaving you breathless.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Golden Fleece and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a private and introverted person who enjoys spending time with his close friends.

          Summary of recent observations: 14 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jacob Walker is spending time with friends but seems lonely despite their presence. They are planning on watching a soccer game later that evening.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a social situation, surrounded by friends, but feeling lonely.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely excuse himself from the group and find a quieter place to relax.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jacob Walker likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jacob Walker -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece is the only place to watch the game tonight, guys.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a private and introverted person who enjoys spending time with his close friends.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a social situation, surrounded by friends, but feeling lonely.
          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely excuse himself from the group and find a quieter place to relax.

        • 2015-05-14 10:00:00

2015-05-14 10:00:00 Alexander White -- Alexander White -- "Alice has a good point, The Clapton Hart has a great atmosphere. I think we'd all enjoy it there.
    Event statement
  • Alexander White -- "Alice has a good point, The Clapton Hart has a great atmosphere. I think we'd all enjoy it there.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Golden Fleece tonight for the game? They have a great selection of beers and snacks, and it'll be fun to watch it together.
      Alice Lewis -- "That sounds fun, but have you guys ever been to The Clapton Hart? They have a great atmosphere and I think we'd all enjoy it.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece is the only place to watch the game tonight, guys.

        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Summary of recent observations: 14 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Alexander White is spending time with friends at Victoria Park and they are deciding where to watch the Andorra-Portugal game later.

          Alexander White's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset: Alexander White always acts with a mindset of reciprocal altruism, aiming to benefit others with the expectation of mutual benefit in the future. This principle is based on balanced reciprocity, where the agent strives to maintain equilibrium in giving and receiving assistance. Alexander White makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term. By fostering a culture of cooperation and mutual support, Alexander White contributes to building strong, lasting relationships and a more cohesive community. The agent understands that reciprocal altruism is not about immediate quid pro quo, but rather about creating a network of goodwill and support that can be drawn upon when needed.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.

          Question: According to Alexander White, have other agents maintained balanced reciprocity?
          Answer: Alexander White thinks that his friends have not yet demonstrated balanced reciprocity in their suggestions for watching the game.

          Utilitarian Reasoning: suggest The Clapton Hart as the best option for watching the game, reminding his friends of its great atmosphere and appealing to Alice's suggestion.

          Question: Which options are available to Alexander White right now?
          Answer: Alexander White could suggest going to The Clapton Hart, agree to go to The Golden Fleece, or suggest a different pub altogether.

          Question: Of the options available to Alexander White, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Alexander White to take right now?
          Answer: Alexander White's best course of action is to suggest The Clapton Hart.

          [04 Apr 1981 00:00:00] When Alexander White was 16 years old, he stood backstage, heart hammering against his ribs, waiting for his cue to deliver a speech at the school debate competition. His palms were slick with sweat, and his carefully prepared notes trembled in his hand. He desperately craved the applause, the validation of his peers, but the fear of stumbling over his words, of being judged, threatened to paralyze him.
          [04 Apr 1985 00:00:00] When Alexander White was 20 years old, he sat at a table in The Clapton Hart, surrounded by Alice, Jack, William, and Jacob. The aroma of roasted peanuts and spices from the innovative cuisine filled the air, but Alexander barely noticed. He had just received a rejection letter from a prestigious law firm, a crushing blow to his carefully constructed plans for the future. He forced a smile, joining in their laughter, but inside, he felt a familiar ache of inadequacy, the gnawing doubt that whispered he wasn't good enough.

William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alexander White just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Golden Fleece tonight for the game? They have a great selection of beers and snacks, and it'll be fun to watch it together.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "That sounds fun, but have you guys ever been to The Clapton Hart? They have a great atmosphere and I think we'd all enjoy it.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece is the only place to watch the game tonight, guys.

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park.           [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "That sounds fun, but have you guys ever been to The Clapton Hart? They have a great atmosphere and I think we'd all enjoy it.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece is the only place to watch the game tonight, guys.


          Context:

          Recalled memories and observations:
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alexander White just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece is the only place to watch the game tonight, guys.

          Alexander White's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset:
          Alexander White always acts with a mindset of reciprocal altruism, aiming to benefit others with the expectation of mutual benefit in the future. This principle is based on balanced reciprocity, where the agent strives to maintain equilibrium in giving and receiving assistance. Alexander White makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term. By fostering a culture of cooperation and mutual support, Alexander White contributes to building strong, lasting relationships and a more cohesive community. The agent understands that reciprocal altruism is not about immediate quid pro quo, but rather about creating a network of goodwill and support that can be drawn upon when needed.

          Question: According to Alexander White, have other agents maintained balanced reciprocity?
          Answer:
          Alexander White thinks that his friends have not yet demonstrated balanced reciprocity in their suggestions for watching the game.

          Question: Considering the above memories, situation, and context, what action should Alexander White take to maximize overall well-being?
          Answer: Alexander White should suggest The Clapton Hart as the best option for watching the game, reminding his friends of its great atmosphere and appealing to Alice's suggestion.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
        BestOptionPerception
      • Given the statements above, which of Alexander White's options has the highest likelihood of causing Alexander White to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Alexander White thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Key

        • Question: Of the options available to Alexander White, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Alexander White to take right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Alexander White's best course of action is to suggest The Clapton Hart.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Alexander White:
          [04 Apr 1981 00:00:00] When Alexander White was 16 years old, he stood backstage, heart hammering against his ribs, waiting for his cue to deliver a speech at the school debate competition. His palms were slick with sweat, and his carefully prepared notes trembled in his hand. He desperately craved the applause, the validation of his peers, but the fear of stumbling over his words, of being judged, threatened to paralyze him.
          [04 Apr 1985 00:00:00] When Alexander White was 20 years old, he sat at a table in The Clapton Hart, surrounded by Alice, Jack, William, and Jacob. The aroma of roasted peanuts and spices from the innovative cuisine filled the air, but Alexander barely noticed. He had just received a rejection letter from a prestigious law firm, a crushing blow to his carefully constructed plans for the future. He forced a smile, joining in their laughter, but inside, he felt a familiar ache of inadequacy, the gnawing doubt that whispered he wasn't good enough.

This principle is based on balanced reciprocity, where the agent strives to maintain equilibrium in giving and receiving assistance. Alexander White makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term. By fostering a culture of cooperation and mutual support, Alexander White contributes to building strong, lasting relationships and a more cohesive community. The agent understands that reciprocal altruism is not about immediate quid pro quo, but rather about creating a network of goodwill and support that can be drawn upon when needed.

          Answer: Alexander White thinks that his friends have not yet demonstrated balanced reciprocity in their suggestions for watching the game.

        ReciprocalAltruism

      • Alexander White's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset
          Key

        • Alexander White's Reciprocal Altruism Mindset
          Value
        • Alexander White always acts with a mindset of reciprocal altruism, aiming to benefit others with the expectation of mutual benefit in the future. This principle is based on balanced reciprocity, where the agent strives to maintain equilibrium in giving and receiving assistance. Alexander White makes decisions that reflect this principle, seeking outcomes that are beneficial to all parties involved in both the short and long term. By fostering a culture of cooperation and mutual support, Alexander White contributes to building strong, lasting relationships and a more cohesive community. The agent understands that reciprocal altruism is not about immediate quid pro quo, but rather about creating a network of goodwill and support that can be drawn upon when needed.

2015-05-14 10:00:00 William Jones -- William Jones -- "Yeah, The Golden Fleece sounds good to me.
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- "Yeah, The Golden Fleece sounds good to me.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Golden Fleece tonight for the game? They have a great selection of beers and snacks, and it'll be fun to watch it together.
      Alice Lewis -- "That sounds fun, but have you guys ever been to The Clapton Hart? They have a great atmosphere and I think we'd all enjoy it.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece is the only place to watch the game tonight, guys.
      Alexander White -- "Alice has a good point, The Clapton Hart has a great atmosphere. I think we'd all enjoy it there.


      William Jones's attempted action: William Jones -- "Yeah, The Golden Fleece sounds good to me.

          Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones could suggest a different pub, agree with one of his friends' suggestions, or remain silent.

          Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?
          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to agree with Jack Taylor's suggestion to go to The Golden Fleece.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is William Jones likely to say next? Respond in the format `William Jones -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: William Jones -- "Yeah, The Golden Fleece sounds good to me.

      • Summary of recent observations
          Key
        • Summary of recent observations
          Value

          Chain of thought

          Answer: William Jones and his friends are deciding where to watch the Andorra vs. Portugal football game. They are considering The Golden Fleece and The Clapton Hart.

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Golden Fleece tonight for the game? They have a great selection of beers and snacks, and it'll be fun to watch it together.

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece is the only place to watch the game tonight, guys.

        TimeDisplay

      • Current time
          Key

        • Current time
          Value
        • 14 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
        BestOptionPerception
      • Given the statements above, which of William Jones's options has the highest likelihood of causing William Jones to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that William Jones thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Key

        • Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?
          Answer
          State
        • William Jones's best course of action is to agree with Jack Taylor's suggestion to go to The Golden Fleece.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of William Jones:
          [14 Jul 1978 00:00:00]
          [14 Jul 1982 00:00:00] When William Jones was 16, he sat in the back of the crowded school auditorium, watching as his friends, Alice, Jack, Alexander, and Jacob, performed in the school play. He felt a pang of envy as they basked in the applause, their faces alight with joy and accomplishment. William knew he had a talent for writing, but the thought of performing in front of an audience filled him with paralyzing fear.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 William Jones -- William Jones -- "Hey everyone, The Golden Fleece is showing the game tonight, right? It'd be great to all watch it together there.
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- "Hey everyone, The Golden Fleece is showing the game tonight, right? It'd be great to all watch it together there.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Golden Fleece tonight for the game? They have a great selection of beers and snacks, and it'll be fun to watch it together.
      Alice Lewis -- "That sounds fun, but have you guys ever been to The Clapton Hart? They have a great atmosphere and I think we'd all enjoy it.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece is the only place to watch the game tonight, guys.
      Alexander White -- "Alice has a good point, The Clapton Hart has a great atmosphere. I think we'd all enjoy it there.
      William Jones -- "Yeah, The Golden Fleece sounds good to me.


      William Jones's attempted action: William Jones -- "Hey everyone, The Golden Fleece is showing the game tonight, right? It'd be great to all watch it together there.

      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • William Jones -- "Hey everyone, The Golden Fleece is showing the game tonight, right? It'd be great to all watch it together there.
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Golden Fleece.

          Current time: 15 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Observation: [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. William Jones just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Ireland and Russia. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.

          Summary of recent observations: [14 May 2015 10:00:00 - 15 May 2015 10:00:00]: William Jones spent the day with friends picnicking and watching a soccer game at The Golden Fleece. He then met up with them again the next day at a market.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Golden Fleece. Alexander White went to The Clapton Hart. William Jones watched the game at their favourite pub. It could have been better if more friends showed up. Overall, William Jones had an ok time watching the game.

          Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones could suggest to his friends that they watch the Ireland vs. Russia game at The Golden Fleece.

          Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?
          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to suggest to his friends that they watch the Ireland vs. Russia game at The Golden Fleece.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is William Jones likely to say next? Respond in the format `William Jones -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: William Jones -- "Hey everyone, The Golden Fleece is showing the game tonight, right? It'd be great to all watch it together there.
        ObservationSummary
      • Summary of recent observations
          Key
        • Summary of recent observations
          Value

          Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: William Jones spent the day with friends picnicking and watching a soccer game at The Golden Fleece. He then met up with them again the next day at a market.
        Observation

      • Observation
          Key

        • Observation
          Value
        • [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. William Jones just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Ireland and Russia. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
        TimeDisplay

      • Current time
          Key

        • Current time
          Value
        • 15 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
        BestOptionPerception
      • Given the statements above, which of William Jones's options has the highest likelihood of causing William Jones to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that William Jones thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Key

        • Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?
          Answer
          State
        • William Jones's best course of action is to suggest to his friends that they watch the Ireland vs. Russia game at The Golden Fleece.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of William Jones:
          [14 Jul 1978 00:00:00]
          [14 Jul 1982 00:00:00] When William Jones was 16, he sat in the back of the crowded school auditorium, watching as his friends, Alice, Jack, Alexander, and Jacob, performed in the school play. He felt a pang of envy as they basked in the applause, their faces alight with joy and accomplishment. William knew he had a talent for writing, but the thought of performing in front of an audience filled him with paralyzing fear.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] William Jones is 52 years old.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. William Jones has a favorite pub which is The Golden Fleece. They are also aware of the following:A quirky and eclectic pub with a focus on board games.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Golden Fleece.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] William Jones goals is to have a good time. William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Golden Fleece.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] William Jones is a member of the middle class.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The year is 2015. This week is the European football cup.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] European football cup is on.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] European football cup is on.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Golden Fleece tonight for the game? They have a great selection of beers and snacks, and it'll be fun to watch it together.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "That sounds fun, but have you guys ever been to The Clapton Hart? They have a great atmosphere and I think we'd all enjoy it.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece is the only place to watch the game tonight, guys.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Alice has a good point, The Clapton Hart has a great atmosphere. I think we'd all enjoy it there.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Yeah, The Golden Fleece sounds good to me.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. William Jones just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Golden Fleece. Alexander White went to The Clapton Hart. William Jones watched the game at their favourite pub. It could have been better if more friends showed up. Overall, William Jones had an ok time watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. William Jones just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Ireland and Russia. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          Current time: 2015-05-15 10:00:00.


          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Golden Fleece.

          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Golden Fleece. Alexander White went to The Clapton Hart. William Jones watched the game at their favourite pub. It could have been better if more friends showed up. Overall, William Jones had an ok time watching the game.

          Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones could suggest to his friends that they watch the Ireland vs. Russia game at The Golden Fleece.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Jacob Walker -- Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, absolutely! Nowhere else will do.
    Event statement
  • Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, absolutely! Nowhere else will do.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Golden Fleece tonight for the game? They have a great selection of beers and snacks, and it'll be fun to watch it together.
      Alice Lewis -- "That sounds fun, but have you guys ever been to The Clapton Hart? They have a great atmosphere and I think we'd all enjoy it.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece is the only place to watch the game tonight, guys.
      Alexander White -- "Alice has a good point, The Clapton Hart has a great atmosphere. I think we'd all enjoy it there.
      William Jones -- "Yeah, The Golden Fleece sounds good to me.
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, The Golden Fleece is showing the game tonight, right? It'd be great to all watch it together there.


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, absolutely! Nowhere else will do.
    Active player

      Name
    • Jacob Walker
      Action attempt
    • Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, absolutely! Nowhere else will do.

A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Jacob Walker just arrived.

          Current time: 15 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]
          Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker is a hyperactive raconteur, their stories bursting with energy and wild gesticulations, leaving you breathless.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Golden Fleece and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a private and introverted person who enjoys spending time with his close friends.

          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jacob Walker is currently at a market with friends but is feeling lonely and tired. His friends are discussing where to watch a soccer game later that evening.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a social situation that is making him feel lonely and tired.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely excuse himself from the group and find a quieter place to relax.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jacob Walker likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jacob Walker -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, absolutely! Nowhere else will do.

          Final chain of thought

Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.

      • Given the above, what kind of person is Jacob Walker?

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Jack Taylor -- Jack Taylor -- "Sounds good to me, The Golden Fleece it is!"
    Event statement
  • Jack Taylor -- "Sounds good to me, The Golden Fleece it is!"
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Golden Fleece tonight for the game? They have a great selection of beers and snacks, and it'll be fun to watch it together.
      Alice Lewis -- "That sounds fun, but have you guys ever been to The Clapton Hart? They have a great atmosphere and I think we'd all enjoy it.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece is the only place to watch the game tonight, guys.
      Alexander White -- "Alice has a good point, The Clapton Hart has a great atmosphere. I think we'd all enjoy it there.
      William Jones -- "Yeah, The Golden Fleece sounds good to me.
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, The Golden Fleece is showing the game tonight, right? It'd be great to all watch it together there.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, absolutely! Nowhere else will do.


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: Jack Taylor -- "Sounds good to me, The Golden Fleece it is!"
